title: Prerequisites & Setup
content:
Setting Up Your Development Environment

Before diving into Angular, let's ensure you have everything needed for a smooth development experience.

System Requirements

  • Operating System: Windows 10+, macOS 10.13+, or Linux
  • Memory: At least 4GB RAM (8GB+ recommended)
  • Disk Space: 2GB+ available space

Required Software

1. Node.js (v18.13.0 or later)

Angular requires Node.js for development tools and package management.

  • Download from nodejs.org
  • Choose the LTS (Long Term Support) version
  • Verify installation by running the commands shown below

2. Package Manager

You'll need either npm (comes with Node.js) or yarn:

  • npm: Included with Node.js installation
  • yarn: Alternative package manager (optional)

3. Code Editor

While you can use any text editor, we recommend:

  • Visual Studio Code - Excellent Angular support with extensions
  • WebStorm/IntelliJ - Powerful IDE with built-in Angular features
  • Sublime Text - Lightweight with good plugin ecosystem

Recommended VS Code Extensions

  • Angular Language Service - IntelliSense and error checking
  • Angular Snippets - Code snippets for faster development
  • TypeScript Importer - Auto-import functionality
  • Prettier - Code formatting
  • ESLint - Code linting and error detection

Browser Requirements

Angular supports modern browsers:

  • Chrome (latest)
  • Firefox (latest)
  • Safari (latest)
  • Edge (latest)

Note: Internet Explorer is not supported in Angular 12+.

Optional but Helpful

  • Git: Version control system for managing your code
  • Angular DevTools: Browser extension for debugging Angular applications
  • TypeScript knowledge: While not required, basic familiarity helps

codeExamples.title: Verify Node.js Installation
codeExamples.description: Run these commands in your terminal to verify Node.js and npm are properly installed.
codeExamples.code:
# Check Node.js version
node --version
# Should output something like: v18.17.0

# Check npm version
npm --version
# Should output something like: 9.6.7

# Check npx availability
npx --version
# Should output npm version (npx comes with npm)
codeExamples.explanation: These commands verify that Node.js, npm, and npx are installed and accessible from your command line. The exact version numbers may vary, but ensure Node.js is v18.13.0 or later.
codeExamples.expectedOutput: Version numbers displayed for each tool, confirming successful installation

codeExamples.title: Create Your Angular Workspace
codeExamples.description: Set up a dedicated folder structure for your Angular learning projects.
codeExamples.code:
# Create a dedicated folder for Angular projects
mkdir angular-projects
cd angular-projects

# Create a workspace for this course
mkdir mastery-hub-workspace
cd mastery-hub-workspace

# Verify you're in the right location
pwd
# Should show your new workspace path
codeExamples.explanation: Creating a dedicated workspace helps organize your Angular projects and keeps your learning materials separate from other development work.
codeExamples.expectedOutput: A clean directory structure ready for Angular development

codeExamples.title: Git Configuration (Optional)
codeExamples.description: If you plan to use version control, configure Git with your information.
codeExamples.code:
# Set your Git username and email
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com"

# Verify configuration
git config --global --list

# Initialize a repository (when you create your first project)
git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"
codeExamples.explanation: Version control is essential for tracking changes in your code. Git is the most popular version control system and integrates well with Angular development workflows.
codeExamples.expectedOutput: Git properly configured and ready to track your Angular projects
